If a function \boldsymbol {f}: \mathbb {R}^n \mapsto \mathbb {R}^m is differentiable at \boldsymbol {x} \in \mathbb {R}^n, then the Jacobian matrix of \boldsymbol {f} at \boldsymbol {x} is the best linear approximation of \boldsymbol {f} at \boldsymbol {x}. It is defined as
\frac {\partial \boldsymbol {f}}{\partial \boldsymbol {x}} = \begin {bmatrix} \frac {\partial f_1}{\partial x_1} & \cdots & \frac {\partial f_1}{\partial x_n} \\ \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ \frac {\partial f_m}{\partial x_1} & \cdots & \frac {\partial f_m}{\partial x_n} \end {bmatrix}

Case of one demension: Let X be a continuous random variable with PDF f_X(x) and Y = g(X) be a function of X with inverse X = g^{-1}(Y). Then the PDF of Y is
f_Y(y) = f_X(g^{-1}(y)) \left | \frac {\mathrm {d}}{\mathrm {d}y} g^{-1}(y) \right |

If a function \boldsymbol {f}: \mathbb {R}^n \mapsto \mathbb {R}^m is differentiable at \boldsymbol {x} \in \mathbb {R}^n, then the Jacobian matrix of \boldsymbol {f} at \boldsymbol {x} is the best linear approximation of \boldsymbol {f} at \boldsymbol {x}. It is defined as
\frac {\partial \boldsymbol {f}}{\partial \boldsymbol {x}} = \begin {bmatrix} \frac {\partial f_1}{\partial x_1} & \cdots & \frac {\partial f_1}{\partial x_n} \\ \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ \frac {\partial f_m}{\partial x_1} & \cdots & \frac {\partial f_m}{\partial x_n} \end {bmatrix}
Let \boldsymbol {X} be a continuous random vector with PDF f_{\boldsymbol {X}}(\boldsymbol {x}) and \boldsymbol {Y} = \boldsymbol {g}(\boldsymbol {X}) be a function of \boldsymbol {X} with inverse \boldsymbol {X} = \boldsymbol {g}^{-1}(\boldsymbol {Y}). Then the PDF of \boldsymbol {Y} is
f_{\boldsymbol {Y}}(\boldsymbol {y}) = f_{\boldsymbol {X}}(\boldsymbol {g}^{-1}(\boldsymbol {y})) \left | \det \left ( \frac {\partial \boldsymbol {g}^{-1}(\boldsymbol {y})}{\partial \boldsymbol {y}} \right ) \right |
